prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

annotationBlock.spanGrp: Some clans, some tribes came from Iraq during Atatürk's era, meaning, when the war happened, something occurred, and the population decreased; there were no longer people living in this area
At that time, Turkey was under Atatürk’s rule, and he sent messages to Greece, Iraq, Syria, Azerbaijan, Iran, and Yugoslavia, saying: 'Give me people! Give me those you don’t want!

For example, here we have the 'Ǧumayle' tribe; we call them the ' Ǧumayle' clan. They came from Iraq, they came from Iraq. Now, in Harran, Atatürk gave them Harran at that time and told them, 'Harran is yours! This area is a gift for you!
Now they are the majority clan; they came from Iraq eighty or ninety years ago. Their ancestor came from Iraq. They all moved and came here

For example, let’s say 'ʕUbāde', there are the 'ʕUbāde' tribe, they came form Iraq and others from Syria. At that time, they were referred to as nomads, moving from place to place. When they arrived at that place and saw it was good, they decided to settle there.

In the old days, because there were no borders between us and Syria, no borders, you could travel from here to Aleppo and back. People would go from here; if they were upset, they’d go there. This way, everyone here gathered with their relatives

For example, let's say there's an 'ʕUbādi' here. An Iraqi ʕUbādi comes from Iraq and says, 'I am ʕUbādi.' The other person says, 'I am also ʕUbādi, come join me!' Then a ' Ǧmayli' comes and says, 'I am Ǧmayli,' and the Ǧmayli here says, 'Come join me!

And each group took an area, each one became a region. For example, the 'Bini ʕIǧil'—now, let's say the ' Bini ʕIǧil' are numerous; they are many here in Harran, many in Syria, many in Iraq, many. They came together and gathered

Some went to Syria, some came to Turkey. Some went to Iraq, meaning they aren’t in one place. One of them came here, saying, 'I came here; I am an ʕIǧli, I came here to this village. Tomorrow, my numbers will increase here; in fifty years, I’ll say: this is mine!' For example

Why did he come in the first place? The whole region of Harran is made up of clans. There is the 'Ḥub¬¬ēṭ,' the 'Ǧumayle,' the 'ʕUbāde,' the 'Siyāle,' the 'Ṭammāḥ,' then the 'Nuwāǧiḥ,' and the 'Maʕāǧle '— the 'Maʕāǧle' are also there. There is the 'ʕAbīd', we are all servants of God. There is the 'Qaǧar', There is the 'Qaǧar', there is the 'Bini Xamīs', there is the 'Bini Xamīs', there is the 'Bini Zēd', there is the 'Mašōr', -- there is the 'Mašōr', there is the 'Mašōr'. There is the ' Bini Sadd', there is the 'Bini Mḥimmad'

For example, the 'Bini ʕIǧil'—let's say their branches; the elders tell us that they have a hundred branches. A hundred? Yes, there are a hundred, a hundred branches. Here in... here in Harran, there are 100 branches. The 'Bini ʕIǧil' is one clan, but it has a hundred branches and a hundred families

Each family has five hundred members, a thousand members, each family. The hundred branches—each branch has five hundred, a thousand members. The same goes for the 'Ǧumayle,' with branches and branches. The same applies to the 'Siyāle.' The 'ʕUbāde' is the same as well

In the city, for example, there have been tribes for a long time. They went there. For instance, let’s say I’m going to the city. There they have become more. Even in the city, there are many tribes. They are all tribes.

The Harran area here is all Arabs, extending from the 'Srūč' region and 'Qōrunšahar.' This entire area is Arab; they have been here from the beginning, meaning they didn’t come here five hundred years ago.

They have been here for three hundred, four hundred, five hundred years. Since when, let's say, they arrived. During the Ottoman rule, as for those who came before, we don’t know about those who came later; we can't make any guesses

As for our ancestors... we can't make any guesses; they came and settled here. Since we became aware, we've been here, asking our elders and grandparents who were here before. But those I know, for example, the 'Ǧumayle,' came from Iraq; we know them. They came eighty years ago

For example, the 'ʕUbāde' came from the south, from Syria, from Iraq, around a hundred or a hundred and fifty years ago. In any case, they came here. The same goes for the 'Bini ʕIǧil.' The 'Bini Sadd' might have also been here long ago or maybe not. There is no exact history, no precise history, but for the last two hundred or one hundred years, all these people have been here. No one left
No one came from elsewhere. People left from here, but no one came from there. Meaning, if you count them, there are a hundred clans over there, and there are a hundred clans here

My teacher, in ancient times—let's say in the time of the elders—regarding the meaning of clans. When the clans and tribes, the Arab army, had gathered in the land of Harran. In the past, they were subject to attacks by the Bedouins. They were called invaders; we called them Bedouins. They used to fear the Bedouins in the old days. The Bedouin

The Bedouins used to come, according to what our elders say. They are said to be like 'gypsies,' coming to steal their possessions, taking their sheep and camels. They would fight them, take their money, and kill them with weapons

The Bedouins in the old days, the Bedouin, came from Syria. The Bedouins came on horseback, like what we call 'gypsies' today—thieves. The Bedouins, that’s why they are called Bedouins. 'The Bedouins have come

A hundred or fifty men would come on donkeys; they would come and take their sheep, their livelihood, even their daughters, and their money. They would abduct them. For this reason, we gradually gathered together. It’s said they gathered in one place, fearing the Bedouins

In the old days, in the wilderness, the military didn’t control every place. There were no police stations. There was no police force. Let’s say they would gather: How many are in our family today? Two hundred people

At night, we were all united... at night, we would stand guard. Guards. Guards. Protecting the tribe. They would stay up until morning, holding weapons or, in the old days, swords or newly introduced rifles. Or they would hold knives and stand guard until dawn

They would guard this entire area—all of Harran. The state even had only one guard. One guard couldn't do anything. There was no military, no police. That guard was the authority over this region. He was its military and its police. As for the tribes, they protected themselves

The tribes were the ones who protected themselves. The clan would gather its own people. It was the one that guarded itself. It armed itself with swords and rifles to protect against raids—raids. We call them raiders, from the Bedouins. The raiders would come and steal from them

Raids mean that they come and plunder—that is, looting, stealing. They come upon a village by surprise, taking its sheep, its livelihood, its money, and killing the men, slaughtering them. They even slaughter their daughters. Yes, they kill everyone in their path

At night, they come to someone’s house; they come and slaughter him and his family. They take his daughter and then also take his sheep. They take his livelihood, his money, and leave. They have no fear of God. They are Bedouins—an ignorant Arab, a return to the age of ignorance. We call them ignorant, from the age of ignorance

So now, for example, I spoke about the Armenians. The Armenians—in the past, the city, the country, was divided into three parts. Part of it was Jewish, part Armenian, and part Muslim—three sections. Each one had its own neighborhood

They were residing there. No one fought with anyone, and no one caused any trouble. When the war happened, the war at that time, in the East, there were no problems between them here—no issues between Armenians or Jews. There were no problems here
Some people would come and go, marry, and exchange with each other, meaning things were good between them. In the East, there were many Armenians, and they began to attack the Muslims

Ha! When Atatürk ruled, when he governed the region, many people left. Their hearts were heavy with grief. Their hearts were hanging (and wanted revenge). And because there was no military, the people seized the opportunity to attack the Armenians and drive them out from there

The Armenians appealed to Russia, but Russia did not respond. And what happened, happened. The people expelled them then. The state did not expel them; the people did. They said to them: We will not kill you, you are poor, but leave this place. Leave here so we don’t slaughter you

And then they came and entered the city, taking with them those who were in the city. Now we have an Armenian here—one person in 'Qōran' who escaped from his family when he was a small boy; he was the only one left from his family. We, the villagers, took him in and raised him, and he is Armenian
They got him married, they got him married, and he converted to Islam. He became a Muslim and was able to see his children and grandchildren here, who are Muslims like us. No one ever bothers them

In the past, Armenians and Jews did not speak to each other. No one bothered them. No one fought with anyone. Jews would come to Muslims, and Muslims would go to Jews. Armenians would come to Muslims, and Muslims would go to Jews
They wpuld buy from each other, exchanging goods. Honestly, no one would bother anyone. Even we are the same. Islam does not accept that. The tribes do not accept it

When the French took Urfa at that time, everyone rose up—the tribes. It was the tribes that rallied against the French. The Kurdish and Arab tribes came together and said, 'We do not accept the French. We want to fight them and drive them out of our country
As for the Armenians and Jews, they did not accept and sided with the French. They were asked, 'Why are you with the French? Aren't we all here together? Why have you become allies with them?'
Then the tribes rose up and expelled the French from here. They drove them out and removed them from our midst. And those—those betrayed us. So they came to our side, saying, 'We are all with you.'
We are one people living in one place. Why did you ally with the French? You are Armenian; what is your interest with the French?
At that time, some went to Syria, and some went to Israel. What was the name of the President of Israel in the past? 'Yitzhak Rabin'—'Moshe Dayan'; 'Moshe Dayan' had his house in the city.
He studied in... He has one eye! He studied in the city. And he had a partner here in the village. He and that one all studied together at school.
When he appeared on television, he said, 'This is my friend from school days.' 'Moshe Dayan,' why have you betrayed this country here? Isn't it yours?
And do the Jews speak Arabic? No, they do not speak Turkish. They speak in Turkish. But they know the language and also speak Turkish. They speak Hebrew. So, they speak two languages.
But no one bothers them, no one fights with them or kills them. Even today, there are some in Israel, some Jews who ask each other: 'Where are you from?' They say: 'I am from Urfa!'
